Barsecco | Miami Venue | PartySlate Skip to content Venues Planners Vendors Ideas Venues Planners Vendors Ideas Barsecco Find Venues / Florida / Miami / Barsecco Unclaimed Barsecco 1421 S Miami Ave, Miami, FL 33131, USA Max Seated 100 Max Standing 100 Request info Favorite Owner hasn't claimed this business If you own this business, claim your profile to update information, add photos, and more. Claim Profile Overview Gallery 0 About Barsecco ABOUT US
Barsecco is a chic restaurant and lounge that morphs from day to night, from bright and airy to sensual and inviting. The breezy canopied terrace, located just off Brickell Avenue, welcomes guests to mix, dine, and rest with diverse seating, hanging vines, and reclaimed barn wood. Inside, a sensual edge is added to an otherwise pleasant space with plush furniture, a towering tree, and low lighting. A pleasant, sociable eating experience is encouraged when the lights dim and beverages are poured, with shared-plates pulled from many cultures and local variations. Fresh ingredients are highlighted in classic and inventive cocktails, as well as beers, bottle service, and an international range of spirits, wine, and champagne. In the later hours, programming infuses energy to ensure the mood is right for a convivial night feel fueled by cocktails, music and late night bites.

The vivid, bold decor of Barsecco creates a joyful, energetic atmosphere for any private dining experience or occasion. It includes both indoor and outdoor venues that provide the ideal ambiance and most Instagrammable backdrop for your party or event. Barsecco has six different spaces available to reserve for your event, all able to host a seated party with dinner and drinks, or a standing cocktail party with drinks and hors d'oeuvres.

Rated number six in Yelp's picks for Top 10 Best Private Party Restaurants near Brickell, Miami, Florida.

Yelp Review:
"I had so much fun at Barseco! My roommates and I came here and ordered a few drinks & laughed the night away. The location is walking distance from other bars so you can bar hop. The drinks were good and food was pretty standard bar food. I loved the music and neon lights. There's lots of outdoor seating that's very secluded so I feel as though it's pretty Covid safe. I can't wait to come back here!!" Event Spaces 1 100 max seated • 100 max standing 6 Barsecco 100 Seated 100 Standing Restaurant Pricing Packages Barsecco hasn't listed their pricing yet. Connect with them directly to get a customized pricing proposal for your event. The Best Prosecco Brands For Your Summer Spritzes, According To Sommeliers My Recipes Subscribe Membership Benefits Recipes Meals Holidays Food Trends News Kitchen Tips & Tools All Videos About Us Newsletter Follow Privacy Notice Terms Of Use Skip to Content Recipes Dinners Fall Recipes Kitchen Tips News search Subscribe sign in September Dinner Ideas Best Nostalgic Desserts Tailgate-Ready Recipes Back-To-School Dinners School Lunch Ideas Entertaining & Parties Wine Headquarters The Best Prosecco Brands For Your Summer Spritzes, According To Sommeliers The Best Prosecco Brands For Your Summer Spritzes, According To Sommeliers These expert-recommended bottles belong in your shopping cart. By Gabby Romero and Maria Miyashiro Updated: May 30, 2025 Elena Noviello // Getty Images Delish editors handpick every product we feature. We may earn commission from the links on this page. It seems like all the best food and drink to come out of Italy starts with "p"— pizza , pasta , prosciutto, Parmesan , prosecco. That last one is Italy's most popular version of bubbly, sparkling wine . Prosecco is often compared to champagne , which is considered to be the benchmark of sparkling wine. So what differentiates them? Prosecco is produced in the Veneto and Friuli-Venezia Giulia wine regions of Italy, while champagne is from Champagne, France. Groundbreaking, huh? Here are some less evident distinctions: prosecco is made using primarily Glera grapes in the Charmat, or tank method, which involves a secondary fermentation in stainless steel autoclaves. Champagne production is more involved and takes more time, thus commanding a higher price point. Champagne permits the use of Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, and Pinot Meunier grapes. Production requires a secondary fermentation in the bottle, known as the Méthode Traditionnelle. The difference in production results in a different bubble experience. Champagne is bottled at a minimum of six atmospheres of pressure, resulting in pinprick, consistent bubbles, while prosecco can be made at as low as one atmosphere. This lower pressure makes for a more frothy bubble that dissipates more easily. So what about the taste? Prosecco is a fruit bomb. It can have notes of peach, apple, pear, melon, and cream, combined with intense floral aromas. You may associate it with sickly sweet flavors, but the sparkling wine can range between four different styles with varying degrees of sugar. So whether you want a crisp and dry celebratory sip or a bubbly base for summer spritzes, you can rely on prosecco to get the job done. To help you pick your perfect bottle, we asked sommeliers and wine experts to share their favorite prosecco brands. Their recommendations run the gamut from versatile crowd pleasers to unique showstoppers. Need some inspo for how to serve them? Check out our favorite spritz recipes here . 1 Massimo Coletti Phoja Prosecco di Treviso Frizzante $22 at SommSelect Some proseccos are comfortable in a supporting role, but this bottle demands to be in the spotlight. Janine Coleman, Maître d'hôtel and Sommelier at Cru Uncorked , describes this prosecco as "a multi-vintage natty wonder that displays quite a bit of earth—a favorite trait of mine. This is definitely one for enjoying on its own!" 2 De Stefani Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore DOCG $26 at letstalkvinowineshop.com "My favorite prosecco is unequivocally the De Stefani Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore DOCG," says Katie Forstner, Sommelier at Urban Hill . "I have so much respect for Alessandro's approach to creating traditional, expressive wines from Venezia, and I think this particular sparkler is one of the most palatable, dynamic, and textured proseccos I've had the pleasure of enjoying." Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 3 Nino Franco Prosecco Rustico $20 at Total Wine Thomas Delasko, Sommelier and General Manager of Via Sophia , says this bottle is his go-to Prosecco. "It offers a delicate harmony of orchard fruits—think crisp apple and ripe pear—paired with fine, persistent bubbles and a clean, dry finish," he says. "Equally at home on its own, paired with food, or in a classic cocktail like a Bellini or Aperol Spritz , its versatility is unmatched." 4 Bisol Jeio Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore DOCG $18 at Total Wine This bottle was recommended by several industry experts—and for good reason. "They are a family-owned winery that has been cultivating grapes since 1542," says Katherine Janowiak, Advanced Sommelier at Jamie's Bottle Shop . The wine is brut in style, so it has a nice balance of fruit and dryness." Joe Mele, Sommelier and co-host of The Wine Pair Podcast , also says it's worth the purchase. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 5 Le Colture Fagher Prosecco Superiore Brut $23 at Wine.com Another one of Mele's favorites is this brut from Le Colture. "We always look for Brut Prosecco as opposed to the more commonly found Extra Dry Prosecco," he says. Le Colture's Fagher strikes the perfect balance of fruity and citrus-forward notes without tasting too sweet. 6 Zardetto Prosecco Brut $12 at Total Wine Mele also recommends Zardetto's brut as an affordable bottle that punches well above its weight. This prosecco is light, clean, and crisp, which makes it the perfect summer sipper. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 7 Santomè Prosecco Rose $15 at empirewine.com Surprise: prosecco can be pink too! "The little bit of Pinot Noir that's blended with the Glera brings a whole new flavor profile," says Erika Vigen, Level III Sommelier at Uvae Kitchen & Wine Bar. "The winery itself is family owned by third-generation wine growers and first-generation winemakers." The added red berry notes from the Pinot Noir make this an especially versatile bottle when pairing with food and pouring in a spritz. 8 Bortolomiol Prior Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore Now 13% Off $24 $21 at shopwinedirect.com This DOCG prosecco is the go-to pick for Nizuniro Altamirano, Sommelier at Bahia Hotel & Beach House's Bar Esquina . "It has an elegant structure, fine bubbles, and a crisp acidity," he says. "I love how it balances freshness with subtle complexity—it's not just a celebratory sip, it’s a wine you can truly appreciate." While he suggests drinking it solo to fully experience the nuance, it's also versatile enough for any kind of spritz. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 9 Batiso Contemporaneo Prosecco Brut Now 14% Off $19 $16 at saratogawine.com Seema Prasad, restaurateur and owner of Harvest Wine Market & Miel , has a few favorite proseccos. This one from Batiso is "just delicious juice that has a clean, tart green apple-flavored finish and a fresh citrusy scent," she says. 10 Domini del Leone Prosecco Spumante Brut $20 at Astor Wines Prasad's other top pick is from Domini del Leone. "Both are farmed organically and are truly brut (less than 12 grams/liter of residual sugar), so super dry on your palate," she says. "You know when you taste a wine and you quickly want to taste more...both of these do that to me." Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 11 santome Tenuta Santomè Prosecco DOC Treviso Brut $15 at empirewine.com Wine expert and importer Lauren Power of Lauren Power Wine and Tre Amici Imports has tasted plenty of prosecco, and this brut from Santomè is her tried and true. "It’s my anytime sparkling. I’ll pop a bottle for happy hour, pair it with salty snacks, or pour a glass when I just want something refreshing and celebratory without overthinking it," she says. "It’s also one of my favorite picks for summer entertaining because it's light, crowd-pleasing, and incredibly versatile." 12 Mionetto Prosecco Brut $14 at Total Wine When you step into any standard wine store, there's one prosecco that you can trust to be always in stock and always delicious. Mionetto's classic brut is crisp, not too sweet, and easy to pair in any cocktail. It's no wonder that it's our test kitchen's favorite prosecco brand.
